instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

threads.title: 820-2936-b
threads.message:
turn on, fan on, no data usb

PPCPUVCCIO_S0_REG_R=1.07
PPVCCSA_S0_REG_R=0.90
PPVCORE_S0_CPU_PH2=0v
PPVCORE_S0_CPU_PH1=0v
PPVCORE_S0_AXG_R=0v
PP1V5_S3=1.5v
PLT_RESET_L=0v

threads.title: 820-2936-b
threads.message:
Missing CPU core may have various causes.
BIOS, PCH, CPU and U7400 are all involved there.
Be sure R7402 is good.

ALL_SYS_PWRGD comes high?

threads.title: 820-2936-b
threads.message:
ALL_SYS_PWRGD=3.2
R7402 is good also 
at one end R7402 has 12.6v and at the other 0.51v is that normal?

threads.title: 820-2936-b
threads.message:
That's normal.
No voltage at all at R7510/20 for sure?

threads.title: 820-2936-b
threads.message: SURE THERE IS NO VOLTAGE, DIODE MODE 0.015

threads.title: 820-2936-b
threads.message:
Any history available?

All the other big coils have voltage?
Compare with good board.

Just in case, try known good BIOS.

threads.title: 820-2936-b
threads.message:
the story is that a battery is placed in it, and after a week I return with the problem, all the voltages are in the coils except
PPVCORE_S0_CPU_PH2=0v
PPVCORE_S0_CPU_PH1=0v
PPVCORE_S0_AXG_R=0v

I already tried bios problem persists

threads.title: 820-2936-b
threads.message:
Just in case, change U7400 and check all surrounding components and solders.
I suspect PCH, or CPU; be sure all voltages from page 22 are good.

You can also try to heat PCH and CPU using quality flux.
